title: about
plain:
About Emma Reyes

Artist, Educator, Explorer

My Artistic Journey

Born and raised in the Pacific Northwest, I've always been drawn to the intersection of natural beauty and human creativity. My journey as an artist began with traditional painting, but quickly evolved to incorporate a diverse range of materials and techniques.

After earning my MFA from the Pacific Northwest College of Art in 2015, I established my studio practice in Portland, where the vibrant art community and proximity to nature continue to inspire my work.

Artistic Approach

My work exists at the crossroads of several disciplines:

Mixed Media Painting - Combining traditional painting techniques with collage and assemblage

Textile Integration - Incorporating hand-stitched elements and fabric remnants

Natural Elements - Using found objects from nature to create texture and meaning

Sustainable Practices - Emphasizing repurposed materials and environmental consciousness

I believe that art should be accessible without sacrificing depth. My pieces invite viewers to approach them on multiple levels—appreciating initial beauty while discovering layers of meaning with continued engagement.

Education & Training

MFA in Contemporary Art Practice - Pacific Northwest College of Art, 2015

BA in Fine Arts - University of Washington, 2011

Artist Residency - Sitka Center for Art and Ecology, 2018

Master Workshop - Mixed Media Techniques with Claire Thompson, 2019

Teaching & Community

Alongside my studio practice, I'm passionate about arts education. I regularly lead workshops for adults and youth at the Portland Art Center, focusing on experimental techniques and creative exploration.

I believe strongly in art as a tool for community building and social change. Through my involvement with the Arts for All initiative, I help bring creative opportunities to underserved neighborhoods throughout Portland.

Personal Influences

My work is deeply influenced by:

The textural complexity of the Pacific Northwest landscape

Japanese aesthetic principles, particularly wabi-sabi

The feminist art movement of the 1970s

Contemporary collage artists like Wangechi Mutu and Mark Bradford

The poetry of Mary Oliver and her attention to natural detail

When not in the studio, you'll find me hiking with my dog Luna, foraging for natural materials, or exploring small galleries and museums across the region.
